'''''Deconica montana''''', commonly known as the '''mountain moss Psilocybe''', is a common species of mushroom that is usually found growing in [[moss]]y areas, often in [[montane]] regions around the world. The appearance is that of a typical "[[Little Brown Mushroom#.22Little brown mushrooms.22|little brown mushroom]]"—with a small, brown cap and a straight, thin stipe, growing separately or in clumps with others.

==Taxonomy==

''Psilocybe montana'' was formerly the [[type species]] of the mushroom [[genus]] ''[[Psilocybe]]''.<ref>Singer, R. (1975). ''The Agaricales in Modern Taxonomy''. J. Cramer, Vaduz. 912 p.</ref>  Because it does not contain [[hallucinogenic]] [[tryptamine]] derivatives like [[psilocybin]] or [[psilocin]],<ref name="Salazar1994">{{cite journal | last1 = Salazar | first1 = F. | last2 = Marcano | first2 = V. | last3 = Castellano | first3 = F. | last4 = Martinez | first4 = L. | last5 = Morales | first5 = A. | year = 1994 | title = Chemical and microstructural study of the genus ''Psilocybe'' (Agaricales) in the Venezuelan Andes: Part I. ''Psilocybe montana'' (Pers. ex Fr.) Kummer | url = | journal = Ernstia | volume = 4 | issue = 1–2| pages = 11–19 }}</ref><ref name="pmid7967656">{{cite journal |author=Marcano, V. |author2=Morales Méndez, A. |author3=Castellano, F. |author4=Salazar, F. J. |author5=Martinez, L. |title=Occurrence of psilocybin and psilocin in ''Psilocybe pseudobullacea'' (Petch) Pegler from the Venezuelan Andes |journal=[[Journal of Ethnopharmacology]] |volume=43 |issue=2 |pages=157–9 |date=July 1994 |pmid=7967656 |doi= 10.1016/0378-8741(94)90013-2|url=}}</ref> it does not stain blue when handled, unlike other typical hallucinogenic members of this genus. Molecular studies in the late 2000s revealed that the genus was [[polyphyletic]] and consisted of two distinct clades separating the blueing species from the non-blueing species.<ref name=Moncalvo2002/><ref name=Nugent2004/><ref name=Matheny2006/> However, dividing the genus would be problematic as the name ''Psilocybe'' was attached to ''P. montana'' and consequently to the non-blueing clade, leaving the hallucinogenic species without a generic name. Because the name is widely associated with the hallucinogenic species and considering the potential legal ramifications of changing their generic name, a proposal was made to conserve the name ''Psilocybe'' with ''[[Psilocybe semilanceata|P. semilanceata]]'' as the type. This left ''Deconica'' available as a name for the non-blueing species.<ref name=Redhead2005/> The proposal was unanimously accepted by the [[Nomenclature Committee for Fungi]] in 2009.<ref name=Norvell2009/>

== Description ==

The cap is 0.5–1.5 cm in diameter, initially convex in shape but flattening in age, sometimes with a broad [[Umbo (mycology)|umbo]]. The cap is moist, [[glabrousness (botany)|glabrous]], [[hygrophanous]], and has radial striations to the center; the color is brown to dark-brown. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are adnate to broadly adnate or sometimes very shortly [[decurrent gills|decurrent]], and of the same color as the cap. The [[Stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is 1.5–4 cm long, 1–2 mm thick, smooth, the same color as the cap, and brittle. [[Spore]]s are typically 7.5–10 × 6–8 × 5–5.5 µm and [[:wikt:ovate|ovate]]–[[:wikt:lentiform|lentiform]] in shape with a thickened wall.<ref name="Miller1982">{{cite journal |jstor=3792745 | last1 = Miller | first1 = O. K. Jr. | last2 = Laursen | first2 = G. A. | last3 = Farr | first3 = D. F. | year = 1982 | title = Notes on Agaricales from Arctic Tundra in Alaska | url = | journal = [[Mycologia]] | volume = 74 | issue = 4| pages = 576–591 |doi=10.2307/3792745 }}</ref> A large spored variety (spore dimensions of 8.5–11 × 6.0–8.5 × 5.0–7.0 µm), ''Psilocybe montana'' var. ''macrospora'' Noordel. & Verduin (1999), has also been reported from the Netherlands.<ref name="isbn90-5410-492-9">{{cite book |author=Bas, Cornelis |title=Flora agaricina Neerlandica: critical monographs on families of agarics and boleti occurring in the Netherlands |publisher=A.A. Balkema |location=Rotterdam |year=1988 |pages= |isbn=978-90-5410-492-6 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> The [[spore print]] is dark greyish brown.<ref name="isbn3-7682-5474-7">{{cite book |author=Gastón Guzmán |title=The genus Psilocybe: a systematic revision of the known species including the history, distribution and chemistry of the hallucinogenic species |publisher=J. Cramer |location=Berlin |year=1983 |pages= |isbn=978-3-7682-5474-8}}</ref>

== Habitat ==

''Deconica montana'' is [[saprobic]], possibly also parasitic. It is often associated with mosses such as ''Brachythecium albicans'', ''B. mutabulum'', ''Campylopus introflexus'', ''[[Ceratodon purpureus]]'', ''[[Dicranum]] scoparium'', ''Eurhynchium hians'', ''E. praelongum'', ''E. speciosum'', ''Rhacomitrium canescens'', ''[[Pohlia]]'' species or ''[[Polytrichum]] piliferum''.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lamoure | first1 = D. | year = 1977 | title = Agaricales de la zone alpine. ''Psilocybe chionophila'', sp. nov | url = | journal = Bull. Soc. Linn. Lyon | volume = 46 | issue = | pages = 213–217 }}</ref> It is commonly found in exposed situations such as dune-meadows, [[Heath (habitat)|heaths]] and tree-less [[tundra]], and open ''[[Pinus]]'' forests, usually on nutrient-poor, well-drained soil.<ref>http://www.entoloma.nl/html/psmontananed.html</ref>
